instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Came in with light corrosion around the edges and the usual places, replaced two of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s and one of their FET's to restore 20V, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area was looking pretty rough so I replaced it for reliability if nothing else.  Charger only pulls .01-.03 amps. 

at <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = Pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP_3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = Pulsing

with <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> removed 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 3.31V
<SIGNAL>PP_3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.31V

Any ideas what to look at first in the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> line?
Many Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> power rail?
Check for short, or low resistance at all S3 and S0 power rails.

Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yeah I tried bypass no luck.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> looks normal but anything <SIGNAL>PP1V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V_S3</SIGNAL> related seems off.

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = .082 V diode
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 160 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> = .082 V diode
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> = 160 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_SUS</SIGNAL> = .052 V diode
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_SUS</SIGNAL> = 117 ohm
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = .194 V diode
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 18 K ohm

Should I be looking to replace <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"at <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = Pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP_3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = Pulsing"
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> should pulse too.
Replace <CHIP>U8200</CHIP>...
